1920 YEAR BOOK UNDER WAY
MURRAY'S LOSS FELT.
Contracts Given Out and Photographer
Secured—Prospects are Bright
for Hullabaloo.

The Hullabaloo Board has been
busily engaged since October 1 in
making the preliminary arrangements for the printing; engraving
and photographic work on the
1920 book. Contracts have already been given out and if plans
continue to progress as rapidly
as they have so far, all will be
ready to start the actual work
within a week or two. Prospects
for the materialization of the aims
of the board to put out an excellent book are very bright indeed,
in view of the fact that the serviees of Paul Wiggins, one of the
photographers for the famous 1917
book, have been obtained, and also
those of several artists from the
Freshman Class, who will assist
the 1920 art editor, "Dick" Cox,
in his efforts to make this year's
Hullabaloo the most attractive,
from an artistic standpoint, that
has ever been published.
Business Manager W. M. Driver, Jr., wishes to announce that
as soon as he can complete the organization of the associate business staff he will start a campaign
for subscriptions, it being his aim
to place a book in the hands. of
every undergraduate. He anticipates little trouble in this, howaver, because of the fact that the
1920 book will be characterized by
its universal attractiveness. Every
Hopkins man will want to own
one.

By FREDERICK TORSCH '20.

To the Class of 1920 and the
other members of the University
that knew him, the sudden loss
of Edwin Emory Murray this
summer brings a feeling of inexpressible shock and regret. While
in bathing at Ocean City, he was
called to aid a companion who
was being carried out of his depth
in the heavy surf and undertow,
especially severe that day. Others
coming up succeeded in bringing
ashore the unconscious man he
was helping, just as Murray himself, spent by holding up the
man, was washed away. Although
every effort has been. made, his
body has not been recovered.
Edwin Murray entered the Engineering Department in February, 1917, and gained an enviable
reputation by his brilliant work
in mathematics and physics II.
When the S. A. T. C. was formed
he was, therefore, one of the first
five to be sent to the Coast Artillery Officers' School at Fort Monroe, from which he received his
reserve commission last January.
He returned immediately to the
University to continue his work
in chemical engineering.
Although of a very quiet nature,
there was something in his disposition, perhaps his loyal appreciativeness, that made his friends
reserve for him an especially deep
regard. He was one of the cleanest, most straight-forward young
men that his intimates have been
privileged to know, and all of his
old companions will treasure the
memories of the times they spent
with him—and of the manner in
which he gave himself at the end.
His family is to be given our
greatest sympathies.
Archaeology Notes.

Charles A. W. Vogeler, a former student of the University,
who died last year, bequeathed
$5,000 to the University in order
to send students abroad to study
Greek archaeology.
Prof. David M. Robinson has
been made editor-in-chief of The
rt Bulletin, a new quarterly.
journal published by the College
Art Association of America, of
which lie has been appointed
president.
On November 13, Dr. Robinson
will lecture on "Ancient Cities of
Asia Minor" before the Dramatic
and Art Association of the New
York State College of Teachers
at Albany, and on the following
day he* will deliver the same lecture at Vassar College. On November 15 he will speak on "The
\Seven Biblical Churches of Asia"
at Wells College.
Prof. Abraham Cohen gave some
courses in mathematics during the
summer session of the University
of Colorado.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1919.
MUSICAL CLUBS ORGANIZE

CLUB HAS GOOD PROGRAM

Enthusiam the Key-Note of First Meeting—About 35 Candidates for the
Clubs—Leaders Engaged.

Many Prominent Men to Lecture--Interest Awakened Among Students
—Officers Expect Good Year. •

The Musical Clubs have resumed
work for the new year. At an
enthusiastic meeting, held in the
Civil Engineering Hall on Monday evening, both the glee and instrumental clubs were organized
and put in shape for the first rehearsal on Monday, October 13.
George S. Cattanach, president
of the Musical Clubs, opened the
meeting with a talk on the history of the clubs at Hopkins, and
urged every man, especially the
freshmen, to enter into the work
of the year with the spirit and
vim which has always character
ized this group in the past, and
which has always brought success. The opportunity for freshmen to make the clubs this season
is greater than ever before, due
to the absence of the usually large
number of upper classmen as well
as to the unprecedented enrollment in the lower class. As will
be remembered the glee club was
reorganized last March and gave
three concerts in June, which,
while not as polished as could
I ave been desired, nevertheless
constituted a good start for the
future. The "new times" ate here
today, it is up to each men individually to put into the Mustif Clubs every ounce of "pep"
he can muster and the result will
, be a year of which Hopkins will
be proud.
Harry Hartman, the leader of
the Haverford Glee Club, has been
engaged as director of the glee
club, while "Doug" Coulter, a
member of the Musical Clubs for
two years, will take charge of the
men with a preference for instrumental music. Both of these leaders are experts in their lines and
with The co-operation of everyone
concerned will turn out an enviable group of musicians.
At the meeting, Defandorf,
treasurer, explained the system of
finances, and Coulter, who is also
manager of the clubs, outlined
plans for the winter trips. Several will be made to the preparatory schools of Baltimore first,
and later in the season concerts
will be given in McCoy Hall;
Washington, D. C., Rockville and
Tome. In addition to the straight
musical , numbers, the programs
this season will include many extra features for which there is an
abundance of talent among the
students. Thirty-five were at the
meeting on Monday, and many
more have given their names to
the directors.
Upper classmen should back up
the clubs as they have in past
years.
Freshmen should not miss the
golden opportunity to make good
in their first year.
Time first rehearsal will be held
in the Civil Engineering Hall on
Monday, October 13, at 8 P. M.

The .Johns Hopkins Social Science Club will have many prominent speakers address it during
the coming winter. Already arrangements have been made to
have R. •W. Bruere, Prof. T. N.
Carver and John Spargo,from out
of the city, and Dr. Lovejoy, Dr.
Hollander and Dr. Barnett, from
the University. These men will
address the club at meetings to
which the public is cordially invited. The first meeting will be
at 4 o'clock, Friday, October 24,
in the Civil Engineering Hall,
and will be addressed by Mr.
Bruere on "Labor Problems of Reconstruction."
Mr. Bruere has been for many
years a student of labor problems
and he holds a high position in
the U. S. Departinent of Labor.
Between each public meeting:
there will be a discussional meeting of the members of the club and
camlidates for membership.
The Social Science Club has the
support of many members of the
faculty and student body, so that
there is no reason why it should
not have a very successful year.
STUDENTS HAND-BOOK SUCCESS;
CONTAINS NEW FEATURES.

The Y. M. C. A. Handbook this
year is one of the best that has
ever been published, with its new
features, large circulation and
neat style. Of special value to
the new men at Hopkins are the
pages devoted to the description
of the various activities, their purpose and their officers. All offices,
political or honorary, have been
listed, so that the names will form
a "Who's Who" of Hopkins. The
usual greeting by the president,
the purpose and plans of the local
Y. M. C. A. and a brief account
of the various branches of work
which the organizantion fosters
occupy the first part of the book.
The schedule blanks, which are of
great value, and then the daily calendar spaces take the main part
of the issue, with all of the advertisements at the back.
There will be issued 1,500 handbooks this year, enough for the
undergraduates, graduates of the
medical and other departments,
as well as all of the faculty. Although the cost of the books700—seemed almost prohibitive,
the need is so great that the Y. M.
C. A. decided to again have an
issue.

The freshman regulations, as
drawp up by the Student Council
.last year, are now in full force.
The only exception to their complete - observance is the lact of
freshman caps and buttons. Copies of these regulations have been
posted in conspicuous places so
that no excuse is accepted for not
complying with them. Already
bands of zealous sophomores have
taken care to inform the ignorant
and punish the flagrant guilty.
There are, however, few of the
latter type. By far the great majority of the freshmen have received the regulations in the spirit
in which they are given, regarding
them not as methods of hazing or
bullying upon the part of the
sophomores, but as traditions and
customs imposed upon- them by
the entire University.
The freshman regulations for
time Class of 1923 are as follows:
1. Freshmen must know the
songs and yells in the Y. M. C. A.
Handbook before the first class
meeting.
2. In crossing the campus,
freshmen must keep to the walks
3. Freshmen may not wear
their bats in any University
4. Freshmen must attend all
time University games and may not
occupy the seats in the stands
other than in the rooting section.
Roll call.
5. No freshman may smoke
while on the University property.
6. Freshmen enter Gilman
Hall by basement only.
7. Freshmen shall wear the
regulation cap, button, black socks
and black necktie (army necktie)
w-imile on University property.
8. In entering doors no freshman may precede an upper classman.
9. Freshmen must not keep
their hands in their pockets while
on University property.
10. Each 'freshman must obey
these regulations until the Easter
holidays.
In order that regulation No. 4
may be more strictly enforced, the
freshmen have been divided into
sections, each of which is under
a sophomore leader. These sections
will be assembled on the quadrangle, in front of • Gilman Hall
shortly before the game and will
then be marched in squad formation to Homewood Field. A list
has been posted on the postoffice
bulletin board containing the
names of the freshmen, the section to which they have been assigned and the place of assembly.
Every freshman must appear on
Saturday, as no excuse for absence will be accepted.

ZIONISTS ORGANIZATION MEETING

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society held its organization meeting on Wednesday, October 8.
Over 40 men were present. In
view of the fact that two class
meetings were taking place at
the same time, it is reasonable to
expect that the normal attendance
will be much ;greater than the
above figure, far outstripping alt•
previous records of the society.
Dean Latane made a brief address, in which he extended his
best wishes for the coming year.
In the course of his talk, he pointed out, among other things, that
the justice of the Jews' claims to
Palestine has been recognized by
the statesmen of the world. Dr.
Latane was followed by Dr. David S. Blondheim, of the French
Department.
Dr. Blondheim's
talk consisted chiefly of 'advice
concerning the work of the coming year. He reminded the members that it is their duty as well
as privilege to investigate the academic phases of the Zionist movement. He urged those present to
maintain the reputation that the
Hopkins Society possesses in the
field of collegiate Zionist activity
—a reputation comparable to that
of the Johns Hopkins University
in the field of education and science.
Following Dr. Illond.heim's addn.:4s there- was a discussion of
''plans for the season. It is intended•to establish a number of study
circles, details of which will be
announced later. Another'feature
will consist of a series of monthly meetings, each to be addressed
by a person of local or national
prominence. These meetings are
open to all Hopkins student,
whether Jewish or non-Jewish,
graduate or undergraduate. Jewish students especially are advised
to await notice of the first meeting of this series.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Unable to participate in
sports myself, I have always taken
the keenest interest in the teams,
especially in their personnel and
co-ordination. For hard work,
small returns and ideal spirit the
track team takes the lead.
Track is a fall, winter and
spring sport; the award of the
Hopkins letter is the most difficult in this sport, for the runner
must win first place in a dual
meet or the equivalent in a championship meet, and there is but
one first place in an event which
but one man can get. Furthermore track requires the hardest
of training, for it is each man
as an individual for himself, with
the slightest letup or weakness
apparent to the whole field. In
a team game one or two men may
be stars and carry along-the other
men. There is. practically no issue of equipment to the track
team, nevertheless each man has
enough spirit and interest to buy
his own outfit. To insure success
in a large meet a squad of 20 to
30 men is necessary; to allow this
number and to give the whole
team a chance, the men on the
first team, or 'Varsity men, have
often paid a part of their own expenses so that some second-string
man may get a chance to win the
Hopkins "H." That's some team
spirit! To send four men to the

NEW CLASSES IN COLLEGE

A course in political science on

given by Dr. Ella Lonn on Wednesday and Friday afternoons,
4:10 to 5 P. M. This course will
be given in Levering Hall, Druid
Hill avenue and Eutaw street. The
first meeting of the course will be
on Friday, October 10.
This course will offer a survey
of the structure of our national
government and intensive study of
state and city government. Important problems of present-day
American city administration,
such as municipal home rule, commission form of government, city
manager, initiative, referendum
and recall will be considered. The
course will consist of lectures,
study of texts as guides and required readings. Time will be reserved at the close of each lecture
for open discussion. It is believed
that the course can be so directed
as to provide sufficient practical
training to enable members to direct intensive classes in citizen-

SCIENTISTS SOON TO RETURN
Williams Memorial Expedition to South
America Gains Valuable
Information.

Although no definite word has
been received concerning the date
of the return of Prof. Edward E.
Berry and Prof. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., of the Johns Hopkins
University, who are now in South
America on the Williams Memorial Expedition, it is generally
thought that they will arrive in
this country about the first of November.
While the geological department
has refused to say anything definite concerning the success of the
trip, it is intimated that much
data of great interest to scientists
has been obtained. For instance,
in the vicinity of the Monte
Blanco tin mines, Dr. Berry found
Devonian fossils at the height of
16,000 feet (more than three
miles), showing that at that time
in the ancient Paleozoic age, commonly called "the age of fishes,".
the rocks now forming the peaks
of the Andes were in a hot seale.vel country.
But, while intent upon making
geological discoveries and taking
care that no fossil escaped their
attention, the Hopkins scientists
were equally observant of the customs and manners of the people
whom they met, and it is most
probable that they will have ail
unlimited number of stories concerning the habits of our South
American neighbors to add spice
to their lectures in the coming
winter.

1920 YEAR BOOK UNDER WAY
MURRAY'S LOSS FELT.
Contracts Given Out and Photographer
Secured—Prospects are Bright
for Hullabaloo.

The Hullabaloo Board has been
busily engaged since October 1 in
making the preliminary arrangements for the printing; engraving
and photographic work on the
1920 book. Contracts have already been given out and if plans
continue to progress as rapidly
as they have so far, all will be
ready to start the actual work
within a week or two. Prospects
for the materialization of the aims
of the board to put out an excellent book are very bright indeed,
in view of the fact that the serviees of Paul Wiggins, one of the
photographers for the famous 1917
book, have been obtained, and also
those of several artists from the
Freshman Class, who will assist
the 1920 art editor, "Dick" Cox,
in his efforts to make this year's
Hullabaloo the most attractive,
from an artistic standpoint, that
has ever been published.
Business Manager W. M. Driver, Jr., wishes to announce that
as soon as he can complete the organization of the associate business staff he will start a campaign
for subscriptions, it being his aim
to place a book in the hands. of
every undergraduate. He anticipates little trouble in this, howaver, because of the fact that the
1920 book will be characterized by
its universal attractiveness. Every
Hopkins man will want to own
one.

By FREDERICK TORSCH '20.

To the Class of 1920 and the
other members of the University
that knew him, the sudden loss
of Edwin Emory Murray this
summer brings a feeling of inexpressible shock and regret. While
in bathing at Ocean City, he was
called to aid a companion who
was being carried out of his depth
in the heavy surf and undertow,
especially severe that day. Others
coming up succeeded in bringing
ashore the unconscious man he
was helping, just as Murray himself, spent by holding up the
man, was washed away. Although
every effort has been. made, his
body has not been recovered.
Edwin Murray entered the Engineering Department in February, 1917, and gained an enviable
reputation by his brilliant work
in mathematics and physics II.
When the S. A. T. C. was formed
he was, therefore, one of the first
five to be sent to the Coast Artillery Officers' School at Fort Monroe, from which he received his
reserve commission last January.
He returned immediately to the
University to continue his work
in chemical engineering.
Although of a very quiet nature,
there was something in his disposition, perhaps his loyal appreciativeness, that made his friends
reserve for him an especially deep
regard. He was one of the cleanest, most straight-forward young
men that his intimates have been
privileged to know, and all of his
old companions will treasure the
memories of the times they spent
with him—and of the manner in
which he gave himself at the end.
His family is to be given our
greatest sympathies.
Archaeology Notes.

Charles A. W. Vogeler, a former student of the University,
who died last year, bequeathed
$5,000 to the University in order
to send students abroad to study
Greek archaeology.
Prof. David M. Robinson has
been made editor-in-chief of The
rt Bulletin, a new quarterly.
journal published by the College
Art Association of America, of
which lie has been appointed
president.
On November 13, Dr. Robinson
will lecture on "Ancient Cities of
Asia Minor" before the Dramatic
and Art Association of the New
York State College of Teachers
at Albany, and on the following
day he* will deliver the same lecture at Vassar College. On November 15 he will speak on "The
\Seven Biblical Churches of Asia"
at Wells College.
Prof. Abraham Cohen gave some
courses in mathematics during the
summer session of the University
of Colorado.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1919.
MUSICAL CLUBS ORGANIZE

CLUB HAS GOOD PROGRAM

Enthusiam the Key-Note of First Meeting—About 35 Candidates for the
Clubs—Leaders Engaged.

Many Prominent Men to Lecture--Interest Awakened Among Students
—Officers Expect Good Year. •

The Musical Clubs have resumed
work for the new year. At an
enthusiastic meeting, held in the
Civil Engineering Hall on Monday evening, both the glee and instrumental clubs were organized
and put in shape for the first rehearsal on Monday, October 13.
George S. Cattanach, president
of the Musical Clubs, opened the
meeting with a talk on the history of the clubs at Hopkins, and
urged every man, especially the
freshmen, to enter into the work
of the year with the spirit and
vim which has always character
ized this group in the past, and
which has always brought success. The opportunity for freshmen to make the clubs this season
is greater than ever before, due
to the absence of the usually large
number of upper classmen as well
as to the unprecedented enrollment in the lower class. As will
be remembered the glee club was
reorganized last March and gave
three concerts in June, which,
while not as polished as could
I ave been desired, nevertheless
constituted a good start for the
future. The "new times" ate here
today, it is up to each men individually to put into the Mustif Clubs every ounce of "pep"
he can muster and the result will
, be a year of which Hopkins will
be proud.
Harry Hartman, the leader of
the Haverford Glee Club, has been
engaged as director of the glee
club, while "Doug" Coulter, a
member of the Musical Clubs for
two years, will take charge of the
men with a preference for instrumental music. Both of these leaders are experts in their lines and
with The co-operation of everyone
concerned will turn out an enviable group of musicians.
At the meeting, Defandorf,
treasurer, explained the system of
finances, and Coulter, who is also
manager of the clubs, outlined
plans for the winter trips. Several will be made to the preparatory schools of Baltimore first,
and later in the season concerts
will be given in McCoy Hall;
Washington, D. C., Rockville and
Tome. In addition to the straight
musical , numbers, the programs
this season will include many extra features for which there is an
abundance of talent among the
students. Thirty-five were at the
meeting on Monday, and many
more have given their names to
the directors.
Upper classmen should back up
the clubs as they have in past
years.
Freshmen should not miss the
golden opportunity to make good
in their first year.
Time first rehearsal will be held
in the Civil Engineering Hall on
Monday, October 13, at 8 P. M.

The .Johns Hopkins Social Science Club will have many prominent speakers address it during
the coming winter. Already arrangements have been made to
have R. •W. Bruere, Prof. T. N.
Carver and John Spargo,from out
of the city, and Dr. Lovejoy, Dr.
Hollander and Dr. Barnett, from
the University. These men will
address the club at meetings to
which the public is cordially invited. The first meeting will be
at 4 o'clock, Friday, October 24,
in the Civil Engineering Hall,
and will be addressed by Mr.
Bruere on "Labor Problems of Reconstruction."
Mr. Bruere has been for many
years a student of labor problems
and he holds a high position in
the U. S. Departinent of Labor.
Between each public meeting:
there will be a discussional meeting of the members of the club and
camlidates for membership.
The Social Science Club has the
support of many members of the
faculty and student body, so that
there is no reason why it should
not have a very successful year.
STUDENTS HAND-BOOK SUCCESS;
CONTAINS NEW FEATURES.

The Y. M. C. A. Handbook this
year is one of the best that has
ever been published, with its new
features, large circulation and
neat style. Of special value to
the new men at Hopkins are the
pages devoted to the description
of the various activities, their purpose and their officers. All offices,
political or honorary, have been
listed, so that the names will form
a "Who's Who" of Hopkins. The
usual greeting by the president,
the purpose and plans of the local
Y. M. C. A. and a brief account
of the various branches of work
which the organizantion fosters
occupy the first part of the book.
The schedule blanks, which are of
great value, and then the daily calendar spaces take the main part
of the issue, with all of the advertisements at the back.
There will be issued 1,500 handbooks this year, enough for the
undergraduates, graduates of the
medical and other departments,
as well as all of the faculty. Although the cost of the books700—seemed almost prohibitive,
the need is so great that the Y. M.
C. A. decided to again have an
issue.

Major Robert W. Wood, who in

membership in the Royal Society
of London. The honor came to
him in recognition of the work
done by him during the war and
in the advancement of physical research. Major Wood is the inventor of tear gas.

The freshman regulations, as
drawp up by the Student Council
.last year, are now in full force.
The only exception to their complete - observance is the lact of
freshman caps and buttons. Copies of these regulations have been
posted in conspicuous places so
that no excuse is accepted for not
complying with them. Already
bands of zealous sophomores have
taken care to inform the ignorant
and punish the flagrant guilty.
There are, however, few of the
latter type. By far the great majority of the freshmen have received the regulations in the spirit
in which they are given, regarding
them not as methods of hazing or
bullying upon the part of the
sophomores, but as traditions and
customs imposed upon- them by
the entire University.
The freshman regulations for
time Class of 1923 are as follows:
1. Freshmen must know the
songs and yells in the Y. M. C. A.
Handbook before the first class
meeting.
2. In crossing the campus,
freshmen must keep to the walks
3. Freshmen may not wear
their bats in any University
4. Freshmen must attend all
time University games and may not
occupy the seats in the stands
other than in the rooting section.
Roll call.
5. No freshman may smoke
while on the University property.
6. Freshmen enter Gilman
Hall by basement only.
7. Freshmen shall wear the
regulation cap, button, black socks
and black necktie (army necktie)
w-imile on University property.
8. In entering doors no freshman may precede an upper classman.
9. Freshmen must not keep
their hands in their pockets while
on University property.
10. Each 'freshman must obey
these regulations until the Easter
holidays.
In order that regulation No. 4
may be more strictly enforced, the
freshmen have been divided into
sections, each of which is under
a sophomore leader. These sections
will be assembled on the quadrangle, in front of • Gilman Hall
shortly before the game and will
then be marched in squad formation to Homewood Field. A list
has been posted on the postoffice
bulletin board containing the
names of the freshmen, the section to which they have been assigned and the place of assembly.
Every freshman must appear on
Saturday, as no excuse for absence will be accepted.

ZIONISTS ORGANIZATION MEETING

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society held its organization meeting on Wednesday, October 8.
Over 40 men were present. In
view of the fact that two class
meetings were taking place at
the same time, it is reasonable to
expect that the normal attendance
will be much ;greater than the
above figure, far outstripping alt•
previous records of the society.
Dean Latane made a brief address, in which he extended his
best wishes for the coming year.
In the course of his talk, he pointed out, among other things, that
the justice of the Jews' claims to
Palestine has been recognized by
the statesmen of the world. Dr.
Latane was followed by Dr. David S. Blondheim, of the French
Department.
Dr. Blondheim's
talk consisted chiefly of 'advice
concerning the work of the coming year. He reminded the members that it is their duty as well
as privilege to investigate the academic phases of the Zionist movement. He urged those present to
maintain the reputation that the
Hopkins Society possesses in the
field of collegiate Zionist activity
—a reputation comparable to that
of the Johns Hopkins University
in the field of education and science.
Following Dr. Illond.heim's addn.:4s there- was a discussion of
''plans for the season. It is intended•to establish a number of study
circles, details of which will be
announced later. Another'feature
will consist of a series of monthly meetings, each to be addressed
by a person of local or national
prominence. These meetings are
open to all Hopkins student,
whether Jewish or non-Jewish,
graduate or undergraduate. Jewish students especially are advised
to await notice of the first meeting of this series.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Unable to participate in
sports myself, I have always taken
the keenest interest in the teams,
especially in their personnel and
co-ordination. For hard work,
small returns and ideal spirit the
track team takes the lead.
Track is a fall, winter and
spring sport; the award of the
Hopkins letter is the most difficult in this sport, for the runner
must win first place in a dual
meet or the equivalent in a championship meet, and there is but
one first place in an event which
but one man can get. Furthermore track requires the hardest
of training, for it is each man
as an individual for himself, with
the slightest letup or weakness
apparent to the whole field. In
a team game one or two men may
be stars and carry along-the other
men. There is. practically no issue of equipment to the track
team, nevertheless each man has
enough spirit and interest to buy
his own outfit. To insure success
in a large meet a squad of 20 to
30 men is necessary; to allow this
number and to give the whole
team a chance, the men on the
first team, or 'Varsity men, have
often paid a part of their own expenses so that some second-string
man may get a chance to win the
Hopkins "H." That's some team
spirit! To send four men to the

NEW CLASSES IN COLLEGE
COURSE FOR TEACHERS.

A course in political science on
.. _thierican Government: Federal,
State and Municipal" will be
given by Dr. Ella Lonn on Wednesday and Friday afternoons,
4:10 to 5 P. M. This course will
be given in Levering Hall, Druid
Hill avenue and Eutaw street. The
first meeting of the course will be
on Friday, October 10.
This course will offer a survey
of the structure of our national
government and intensive study of
state and city government. Important problems of present-day
American city administration,
such as municipal home rule, commission form of government, city
manager, initiative, referendum
and recall will be considered. The
course will consist of lectures,
study of texts as guides and required readings. Time will be reserved at the close of each lecture
for open discussion. It is believed
that the course can be so directed
as to provide sufficient practical
training to enable members to direct intensive classes in citizen-

SCIENTISTS SOON TO RETURN
Williams Memorial Expedition to South
America Gains Valuable
Information.

Although no definite word has
been received concerning the date
of the return of Prof. Edward E.
Berry and Prof. Joseph T. Singewald, Jr., of the Johns Hopkins
University, who are now in South
America on the Williams Memorial Expedition, it is generally
thought that they will arrive in
this country about the first of November.
While the geological department
has refused to say anything definite concerning the success of the
trip, it is intimated that much
data of great interest to scientists
has been obtained. For instance,
in the vicinity of the Monte
Blanco tin mines, Dr. Berry found
Devonian fossils at the height of
16,000 feet (more than three
miles), showing that at that time
in the ancient Paleozoic age, commonly called "the age of fishes,".
the rocks now forming the peaks
of the Andes were in a hot seale.vel country.
But, while intent upon making
geological discoveries and taking
care that no fossil escaped their
attention, the Hopkins scientists
were equally observant of the customs and manners of the people
whom they met, and it is most
probable that they will have ail
unlimited number of stories concerning the habits of our South
American neighbors to add spice
to their lectures in the coming
winter.
